articles.headline: Five Illuminating Takeaways From Your Family Money Letters
articles.snippet: Readers had some hard-won insights that you may want to borrow when imparting wisdom to your children or relatives.
articles.abstract: Readers had some hard-won insights that you may want to borrow when imparting wisdom to your children or relatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Joe Olivier asked what his niece wanted as a high school graduation present this year, she asked for a couple of thousand dollars in gift cards. She got a letter instead.

articles.headline: How ‘Brexit’ Will Affect the Global Economy, Now and Later
articles.snippet: Stock market declines aren’t too worrying, but a recession is a major risk in Britain and something of a risk in the rest of Europe and the U.S.
articles.abstract: Stock market declines aren’t too worrying, but a recession is a major risk in Britain and something of a risk in the rest of Europe and the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: Things fall apart. And now, “things” includes the European Union.

articles.headline: Countrywide Mortgage Devastation Lingers as Ex-Chief Moves On
articles.snippet: The government has closed the books on its inquiry into Angelo Mozilo, the former leader of Countrywide, but the company’s deeds have had long-lasting impact.
articles.abstract: The government has closed the books on its inquiry into Angelo Mozilo, the former leader of Countrywide, but the company’s deeds have had long-lasting impact.
articles.lead_paragraph: Angelo Mozilo can finally get on with his life.

articles.headline: Some Early Signs of ‘Brexit’ Upheaval
articles.snippet: Some companies are rethinking operations in Britain, both current and planned.
articles.abstract: Some companies are rethinking operations in Britain, both current and planned.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Only hours after Britain decided to leave the European Union, Emmanuel Lumineau cast his own “remain” vote — with his feet. Mr. Lumineau said he would move to Paris from London and take about 10 employees at his financial start-up with him.

articles.headline: ‘Brexit’ Aftershocks: More Rifts in Europe, and in Britain, Too
articles.snippet: The British pound and stock prices plummeted, there was immediate pressure for another referendum on Scottish independence, and David Cameron said he would resign by October.
articles.abstract: The British pound and stock prices plummeted, there was immediate pressure for another referendum on Scottish independence, and David Cameron said he would resign by October.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s startling decision to pull out of the European Union set off a cascade of aftershocks on Friday, costing Prime Minister David Cameron his job, plunging the financial markets into turmoil and leaving the country’s future in doubt.

articles.headline: Energy Transfer Wins Ruling on Escaping Williams Deal
articles.snippet: A Delaware judge decided that a $38 billion merger of two pipeline giants could be abandoned over a discovery that it might not be tax-free.
articles.abstract: A Delaware judge decided that a $38 billion merger of two pipeline giants could be abandoned over a discovery that it might not be tax-free.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Delaware judge ruled on Friday that the Dallas pipeline operator Energy Transfer Equity is entitled to terminate its $38 billion merger with the Williams Companies, culminating one of the most contentious cases of buyer’s remorse in recent memory.

articles.headline: Among Young Britons, Fear and Despair Over Vote to Leave E.U.
articles.snippet: The referendum on Britain’s membership in the European Union exposed sharp generational divisions.
articles.abstract: The referendum on Britain’s membership in the European Union exposed sharp generational divisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — As the bands played on at the Glastonbury music festival in Somerset, England, Lewis Phillips and his friends drowned their sorrows in song and alcohol.
articles.byline: By Claire Barthelemy and Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura

articles.headline: Low-Priority Immigrants Still Swept Up in Net of Deportation
articles.snippet: After Thursday’s Supreme Court decision, President Obama said immigrants who would have been protected would still be safe, but thousands of deportation operations per week are sweeping up immigrants with minor or no offenses.
articles.abstract: After Thursday’s Supreme Court decision, President Obama said immigrants who would have been protected would still be safe, but thousands of deportation operations per week are sweeping up immigrants with minor or no offenses.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three agents knocked on the door of a modest duplex in a Wisconsin town just after dawn. The Mexican immigrant living on the ground floor stuck his head out

articles.headline: After ‘Brexit’ Vote, Investors Are Gripped by a Panic Last Seen in 2008
articles.snippet: Similarities to past economic crises have presented a grim question: How ugly might things get?
articles.abstract: Similarities to past economic crises have presented a grim question: How ugly might things get?
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — First came the shock. Then fear seized world markets. As frenzied selling accelerated in Tokyo, Hong Kong and London, unfathomable amounts of wealth vanished in a matter of hours.

articles.headline: Is ‘Brexit’ the Precursor to a Donald Trump Presidency? Not So Fast
articles.snippet: Some impulses that drove the vote to leave the European Union are at play in the presidential race, but the differences are just as stark.
articles.abstract: Some impulses that drove the vote to leave the European Union are at play in the presidential race, but the differences are just as stark.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Britain’s vote to withdraw from the European Union sent a shudder through the capital on Friday as the forces of economic nationalism and working-class fury forced American political leaders to wonder: Could it happen here?
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: European Leaders Tell a Dazed Britain to Get Going on ‘Brexit’
articles.snippet: There were clear indications Saturday of a tense and bickering divorce, as European leaders urged Britain to hurry up and begin its departure.
articles.abstract: There were clear indications Saturday of a tense and bickering divorce, as European leaders urged Britain to hurry up and begin its departure.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — With British politics in turmoil, there were already clear indications on Saturday of a tense and bickering divorce from the European Union.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Dan Bilefsky

articles.headline: When You Dial 911 and Wall Street Answers
articles.snippet: Since the 2008 financial crisis, private equity firms have increasingly taken over public services like emergency care and firefighting, often with dire effects.
articles.abstract: Since the 2008 financial crisis, private equity firms have increasingly taken over public services like emergency care and firefighting, often with dire effects.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Tennessee woman slipped into a coma and died after an ambulance company took so long to assemble a crew that one worker had time for a cigarette break.
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory, Ben Protess and Kitty Bennett

articles.headline: ‘Brexit’ in America: A Warning Shot Against Globalization
articles.snippet: Britain’s vote to leave the E.U. may not bring recession to the U.S., but it could mark the end of a period of economic integration and open markets.
articles.abstract: Britain’s vote to leave the E.U. may not bring recession to the U.S., but it could mark the end of a period of economic integration and open markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the mills that birthed the industrial revolution in cities like Manchester and Birmingham still powered the British economy of the mid-20th century, Robert Stevenson was a frequent visitor to the Midlands.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Patricia Cohen

articles.headline: In Search of the Felon-Friendly Workplace
articles.snippet: By pitching ex-cons as good for business, the Eastern District of Missouri’s prison-to-work program has become a model for inmate re-entry nationwide.
articles.abstract: By pitching ex-cons as good for business, the Eastern District of Missouri’s prison-to-work program has become a model for inmate re-entry nationwide.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Rick Plowman’s business, installing suspended ceilings in offices, schools and hotels, could use new blood. But hiring is tough, he tells the man sitting in his office. The 20-somethings he sees haven’t had the work ethic, haven’t had the hustle.

articles.headline: ‘Brexit’ Revolt Casts a Shadow Over Hillary Clinton’s Cautious Path
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton offers messages about stability that are similar to the ones put forth by the defeated “Remain” campaign in Britain’s referendum on leaving the European Union.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton offers messages about stability that are similar to the ones put forth by the defeated “Remain” campaign in Britain’s referendum on leaving the European Union.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Hillary Clinton, Britain’s emotionally charged uprising against the European Union is the sort of populist victory over establishment politics that she fears in the coming presidential election.

articles.headline: Britain Rattles Postwar Order and Its Place as Pillar of Stability
articles.snippet: A historic vote to leave the European Union is raising questions about the future of the post-1945 order imposed on the world by the United States.
articles.abstract: A historic vote to leave the European Union is raising questions about the future of the post-1945 order imposed on the world by the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s historic vote to leave the European Union is already threatening to unravel a democratic bloc of nations that has coexisted peacefully together for decades. But it is also generating uncertainty about an even bigger issue: Is the post-1945 order imposed on the world by the United States and its allies unraveling, too?
articles.byline: By Jim Yardley, Alison Smale, Jane Perlez and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: ‘We’re an Easy Target’: Taken In by the Trump Brand
articles.snippet: Several enterprises stamped with the Trump brand have been accused of preying upon desperation, inexperience or vanity.
articles.abstract: Several enterprises stamped with the Trump brand have been accused of preying upon desperation, inexperience or vanity.
articles.lead_paragraph: The sales pitches seeking to separate Cheryl Lankford from her money began during the recession as she struggled to get back on her feet after the death of her husband, an American soldier serving in Iraq.

articles.headline: Fractures From ‘Brexit’ Vote Spread Into Opposition Labour Party
articles.snippet: Internal criticism of the leader, Jeremy Corbyn, led to his firing the shadow foreign secretary, and at least 11 other members of the party’s cabinet resigned.
articles.abstract: Internal criticism of the leader, Jeremy Corbyn, led to his firing the shadow foreign secretary, and at least 11 other members of the party’s cabinet resigned.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s political crisis intensified on Sunday after its decision to leave the European Union, with the opposition Labour Party splitting into warring camps, Scotland’s leader suggesting that its local Parliament might try to block the departure and many Britons wondering if there was a plausible way for the nation to reconsider its drastic choice.

articles.headline: Donald Trump and R.N.C. Crack Down on Rebelling Delegates
articles.snippet: The Trump campaign and the party’s national committee are moving fast to quash any potential effort to stage a revolt at the convention next month.
articles.abstract: The Trump campaign and the party’s national committee are moving fast to quash any potential effort to stage a revolt at the convention next month.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Trump campaign and the Republican National Committee are moving quickly and aggressively to head off the fledgling effort to stage a revolt at their convention next month in Cleveland, hoping to spare the party an embarrassing spectacle that could deeply wound the presumptive nominee.

articles.headline: C.I.A. Arms for Syrian Rebels Supplied Black Market, Officials Say
articles.snippet: Some of the weapons linked to thefts by Jordanian intelligence operatives are believed to have been used last year to kill two Americans and three others.
articles.abstract: Some of the weapons linked to thefts by Jordanian intelligence operatives are believed to have been used last year to kill two Americans and three others.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Weapons shipped into Jordan by the Central Intelligence Agency and Saudi Arabia intended for Syrian rebels have been systematically stolen by Jordanian intelligence operatives and sold to arms merchants on the black market, according to American and Jordanian officials.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Ali Younes

articles.headline: Volkswagen Faces Long Road Ahead, Even After a Civil Settlement
articles.snippet: A broad settlement that is expected to dwarf all previous deals is taking shape, but the Justice Department is still investigating criminal charges.
articles.abstract: A broad settlement that is expected to dwarf all previous deals is taking shape, but the Justice Department is still investigating criminal charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as the warring parties in Volkswagen’s emissions cheating scandal prepare to offer a peace proposal this week, the German automaker’s travails are far from over.

articles.headline: Perdue Aims to Make Chickens Happier and More Comfortable
articles.snippet: The poultry producer’s plans to improve conditions for its chickens could force competitors to adopt similar measures.
articles.abstract: The poultry producer’s plans to improve conditions for its chickens could force competitors to adopt similar measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEAFORD, Del. — Sunlight floods the floor at one end of the chicken house here at Ash-O-Ley Acres, and spry little Cornish game hens flap their wings and chase one another.

articles.headline: Central Banks Worry About Engaging World Markets After ‘Brexit’
articles.snippet: Some economists warn that the policies largely favored by the banks could further alienate the public and increase the frustration that encouraged Britons to vote for leaving the European Union.
articles.abstract: Some economists warn that the policies largely favored by the banks could further alienate the public and increase the frustration that encouraged Britons to vote for leaving the European Union.
articles.lead_paragraph: As global markets reel after an establishment-rattling vote by Britain to sever ties with Europe, investors are again expecting central banks to ride to the rescue.

articles.headline: At Cannes, the Ad Industry Confronts the Rise of Facebook
articles.snippet: As Facebook commands a growing share of advertising revenue, and ad executives voice suspicion, Facebook itself talks of cooperation.
articles.abstract: As Facebook commands a growing share of advertising revenue, and ad executives voice suspicion, Facebook itself talks of cooperation.
articles.lead_paragraph: CANNES, France — The invasion has begun.

articles.headline: After ‘Brexit,’ a Splitting Hangover for the City of London
articles.snippet: It’s an uncertain new day for financial professionals in Britain, many of whom see “Brexit” leaving hard-won clout behind.
articles.abstract: It’s an uncertain new day for financial professionals in Britain, many of whom see “Brexit” leaving hard-won clout behind.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Luke Hickmore had an aperitif Thursday night, watched the early results on Britain’s vote to leave the European Union and went to bed. He didn’t sleep long.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim and Prashant S. Rao

articles.headline: How Housing’s New Players Spiraled Into Banks’ Old Mistakes
articles.snippet: Some private equity firms that came in as the cleanup crew for the housing crisis are now repeating errors that banks committed, while others are bypassing the working poor.
articles.abstract: Some private equity firms that came in as the cleanup crew for the housing crisis are now repeating errors that banks committed, while others are bypassing the working poor.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the housing crisis sent the American economy to the brink of disaster in 2008, millions of people lost their homes. The banking system had failed homeowners and their families.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein, Rachel Abrams and Ben Protess

articles.headline: With ‘Brexit,’ Washington’s Direct Line to the Continent Suddenly Frays
articles.snippet: Officials say no country shares the United States’ worldview quite the way Britain does in terms of security, intelligence and trade.
articles.abstract: Officials say no country shares the United States’ worldview quite the way Britain does in terms of security, intelligence and trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: American officials struggling to reimagine their strategy after Britain’s decision to divorce the European Union say the most urgent challenge will be to find a way to replace their most reliable, sympathetic partner in the hallways of European capitals. It will not be easy.

articles.headline: Economic Fears Rising, Britain Hopes to Stay in E.U. Market
articles.snippet: Leaders on both sides of the “Brexit” debate signaled that they wanted continued access to the free-trade zone, though the European Union may have other ideas.
articles.abstract: Leaders on both sides of the “Brexit” debate signaled that they wanted continued access to the free-trade zone, though the European Union may have other ideas.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Four days after a decisive vote to leave the European Union, Britain was consumed on Monday with questions of when and how the country’s departure from the bloc would happen — and increasingly, of whether it would happen at all.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger, Stephen Castle and Sewell Chan

articles.headline: Supreme Court Strikes Down Texas Abortion Restrictions
articles.snippet: Had the justices upheld the regulations, the number of abortion clinics in the state would have dropped to 10.
articles.abstract: Had the justices upheld the regulations, the number of abortion clinics in the state would have dropped to 10.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday reaffirmed and strengthened constitutional protections for abortion rights, striking down parts of a restrictive Texas law that could have drastically reduced the number of abortion clinics in the state, leaving them only in the largest metropolitan areas.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Vacates Ex-Virginia Governor’s Graft Conviction
articles.snippet: Bob McDonnell, a former governor of Virginia, did only routine favors in exchange for gifts from a businessman, the justices ruled in a closely watched corruption case.
articles.abstract: Bob McDonnell, a former governor of Virginia, did only routine favors in exchange for gifts from a businessman, the justices ruled in a closely watched corruption case.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday made it harder to prosecute public officials for corruption, unanimously overturning the conviction of Bob McDonnell, a former governor of Virginia.
